reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shallow Space is solid game with excellent core mechanics in place. While the game is fun as it currently is, it still needs some fleshing out and the inclusion of more content but that of course is to come in future updates.

Right now, the biggest thing the game suffers from is the lack of game content which was not been implemented yet (however, the game still has a rather large amount lot of stuff to do at this point)
-----------------------------------------------------------------

Some notable things:
-Excellent ship editor (while you cannot customize aspects of your ship such as the different segments, there will be modular ships that you can customize quite freely in the near future)

-The UI has been changed and enhanced to be more user friendly while retaining all the intuitive and strategic information and elements (With courtesy of the community and their suggestions on how to improve the UI)

-For an indie game with a small budget, the games graphics are top notch. Everything from the backgrounds to the little turrets on the ships have incredible detail and look amazing.

-The game is incredibly well optimized despite being in such an early state. Unless you're running a commodore 64 then you will experience some fps drop, but only in the ship editor since that has some kinks to be worked out.

-Music ain't no Han Zimmer but it's still quite catchy and very atmospheric, it's nice to listen to while you're fighting an enemy.

-And while on the topic of atmosphere, the game's setting (space) has a beautiful amount of detail and the environment feels quite welcoming. Lots of color, very lively. It feels like space proper, but without the blandness that is so commonly seen in many space games today.

-Combat is very fun to work with. The best comparison would probably be a total war in space. That is, you're lugging this big ships at other big ships but there is still quite a bit of strategy when it comes to handling your ships and positioning them.
-----------------------------------------------------------------

There's a lot to look forward to but it hasn't quite yet reached it's highest point. Check out the roadmap for an overview of what's to come: http://shallow.space/roadmap/

Also check out http://shallow.space/the-setting/ for some more little details regarding the game (actually just check out the whole website: http://shallow.space/)

If you're on the verge of buying this because you believe it will fall prey to the eternal early access plague, then you should probably dispell your fears of that happening. While words from some random player may not be the most convincing, I can still truthfully say that the developer has worked diligently and unceasingly for a two years on his own and it wasn't until about 4 months ago that he finally got a crew to work on this game (and when he did updates came out like crazy). Right now we're getting huge content updates every 2-3 weeks and, unlike most EA developers I've seen, this guy gets updates out quickly and relentlessly. He's pretty passionate about his game and has not even shown any prospects of giving up on the game and letting it die during the two years he's been working with it. Full steam ahead and a lot of enthusiam coming from the guy. Probably the one early access developer you can believe in methinks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: Early Access Review, 2016-04-03
TL;DR was TL;DR: Buy it. Right now. Video review at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HzwwVeWKwNc

TL;DR: Do you like Rome: Total War? Do you like Homeworld? Then you absolutely must buy this game. Are you a fan of RTSs but never played Rome or Homeworld? Give it a try anyway. Are you a CoD or DOTA player who's never touched real time strategy? Buy it for the pretty spaceships and explosions. Basically, buy it.

So, what is it? In short, it's Rome: Total War in space. Line up armies, face them off against eachother. A campaign mode is coming, but is not here yet. It's so much more, as well; ship and fleet customization give it a whole extra dimension of depth above most RTSs. Nonetheless, it's very intuitive and feels incredibly responsive.

The good:
Graphics and UI are beautiful and very well designed
The UI, while not typical of RTS games, is impressively intuitive. I went from how do I move" to feeling like Ender in  about ten minutes

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a game in Early Access, the potential is definitely there. Being able to customize your ships in both appearance and loadouts is a great feature. The visuals are certainly stunning, from the ships to the skybox, there is lots of eye candy outside of just the explosions.

The drawbacks are that there is not a whole lot to do at the moment, meaning the single-player campaign is not in place, no Multiplayer, and the ship selection is still fairly small. Of course, these things are all planned features, but the level of communication and activity level from the devs shows that they are committed and passionate about finishing the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It has been a while since we've goten a good Real Time Tactics games. So long in fact, when you consider tha Nexus the Jupiter Incident was pretty much the only one.

Considering that it is in ALPHA -let me stress again ALPHA (so expect the occasional bug)- it is still a solid product, that has one of the most responsive, consistent, and interactive devs I have ever meet. The visuals are absolutely gorgeous, the ships beautiful, and the atmosphere being built around in te Shallow Space universe is totally indepth.

Shallow Space, even in its current iteration is gently, but surely scratching that itch, left by Nexus.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I don't play RTS games, so I cannot really compare this game to anything else.  But, although I am unfamiliar with the genre, I can tell that Shallow Space is aiming to be something unique.  Most importantly, the game is in early access, but the developers are very active on their website and on Steam, and respond to almost every post; whether it be feedback, praise, criticism, or just general questions.

Disclaimer: This part of the review is about the game as of 22, February, 2016, and will likely change with further additions/changes to reflect the current state of the game.

As for the gameplay, currently it is all about outfitting your ships and building up your fleet to send into battle.  Right now, there are a few Skirmish matches and a simulation mode, which allows you to test out your custom or generated fleets and flotilla configurations against a similar fleet of AI.  You can choose to mirror your exact fleet for the enemy to see how well you perform with certain ships, and possibly see how the AI uses them to better advantage.  There is a lot of depth to how the ships can be set up and positioned, as you have a fully traversable 3d environment.  Plotting the courses for your ships to take is a dream and even at this very basic level of functionality is quite intuitive to use.

The ship design is gorgeous.  There is a ton of detail in the models, and the visuals for the backdrops are similarly amazing.  You can customize every ship in your fleet with various kinetic and energy based weapons, outfit them with extra generators for more power, deeper scanning radius, and you can issue further commands from Carrier or Capital class vessels, such as deplying smaller Corvettes or issuing focused-fire commands.  Future updates will include resource gathering and station building/management, added depth to ship shields and weapon mechanics, and much more.

There are some crashes and a few bugs here and there, but for Early Access the optimization is great and it runs really well.  Most negative reviews on Steam are from user-error through interface malfunction or bug related issues, but much of that seems to have been corrected by now.

The developers have some amazing things planned for this game, and they are very passionate about making it as good as it can possibly be.  A planned feature is to let you take executive control of your ships in battle, and to expand the current skirmish style gameplay into a more open-world one.  If you like space games, and you want to command a massive fleet of warships either to engage in all- out tactical 3D combat, or if you just want to  SEND THEM ALL TO DIE....then this game is definitely one for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just launched on EA and still in early alpha stage, I wouldn't recommend it for a general audience yet as there is only a limited set of the features to come implemented. It currently features a small portion of the ships/weapons/modules that will be available, two skirmish battle missions you can play on four maps, and ship customization designer.

Having said that, it has huge potential and is on track to become the definite must-have spacefleet battle simulator game of 2016. Sitting kinda in-between the strategic elements of Homeworld and the tactical focus of Nexus, it is a nice breath of fresh air for the genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After UPDATE 7 of the game i have to revisit this review to reflect the current state of things.

The game plays without problem now in a Ubuntu system with :
AMD Phenom II X4 965
4 GB RAM
200 €  nvidia GPU + propriatery driver

In my debian 8 + amd 5870 + radeon open driver i cant play the game. (it has 16 GB RAM and
i7 cpu so definately RAM in not the main issue here, or cpu power).





I keep my first review below-------

I love the 3d space movement and using spheres in the UI, My main problem is that although i think my system covers the middle ground of the requirements i experience issues of stability and crashes in game and in the fleet compose screen.

So i reccomend this game to linux users with a warning to pay close attention to their system  and driver
and assuming that in an Early Access Game those issues are common, ( i hope for not long!)
For example my card Radeon 5780 is higher in GFlops from the recommended R9 270X but i have half
the memory 4GB. With opendriver radeon the game wasnt playaple (graphics were tones darker) and with
the catalyst closed one thinks are better.

I'd like to hear from other linux users their experience in relation with their system.
Putting the technical issues aside the game is promising and bring fresh ideas in the genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shallow Space is a deep, unique, and beautiful RTS! Even though the game is only in early access at the moment the devs are frequently updating and adding to the gameplay experience. This will doubltessly be a game for anyone who is looking for a space RTS that has depth and customization.

Pros:
- Devs are very active interacting and taking community feedback - they're also plugging away at this game basically every 2 weeks a big update hits in the Alpha so far
- Customization of ships is pretty awesome a good number of modules to choose from that can really vary a fleet
- GRAPHICS!!! I'm not normally a graphic ♥♥♥♥♥ but the ships and the enviornements are beautfully rendered. Even little things like shield resisters lighting up when a ship gets hit blow me away especially considering the game is only in Alpha
- The Devs also have a pretty clear roadmap so you should have a pretty good idea of what the game will include which is nice considering sometimes Early Access games offer a lot of vague promises

Cons:
- Not every system is in the game you might say duh its a EA title, but it does leave for less replayability than the beta or of course the final product will have
- only 1 of the 8 factions that will be in the game is playable right now
- Some systems aren't clearly explained as I'd like (tooltips)

Overall it is shaping up to be a great game! While I can't wait for the final product I have already managed to put 10 hours in it! For up to date videos on the most current iteration of Shallow Space check out some videos I've posted:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL8cNlze3fGQgJsXeq3gCGSNKyPnvCBr-J

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This a very interesting game from what I see, it's kinda like if Homeworld, Nexus TJI, Sins of a solar empire and FTL fused together to make an ULTRA SUPER SPACE 4X RTS!!! or something like that...

The things that I like about the game right off the bat is the customization of you fleet. Not only can you change the color of each ship you enlist in your military force, you can also choose their loadouts in terms of weapons, sensor equipment, shield enhancements as well as energy modules. So you have fun blast away your feeble foes and look good doing it.

UNLEASH THE PINK BATTLESHIPS!!!

Space combat feels very much like nothing I've seen in a space game. It's a beautiful mesh of homeworld ship scaling and Nexus the jupitur incident's combat manuevers, when the capital ships engage they are constantly flying and zipping around it's target dealing damage while fighters fly around with guns ablazing trying set its enemy ablaze! It's very easy to get lost in the beauty of it all.... until you notice that huge explosion at the corner of you screen was your best battleship.

Exploration is an amazing thing to see in a game like this. I thought it was going to just be like a traditional rts but instead, it's going to also have 4x elements to the game! Having a persistant fleet and traveling the stars in search of glory sounds like a joyride in my book.

As for the cons the most obvious one is that since it's early access you will run into some bugs here and there. Now the one I see a lot are nervous buyers that like what they see but feel a cold shiver go down their neck once they see the tag Early Access"
date: I too also dread to see that tag as well. Also theres no multiplayer and I'm also not sure if it will be implemented since it's primarily a singleplayer game. so you could either wait for release for the game or hop in ready to help make this game become one of the best space games on the market
recommended:
your choice.

Me? I'm blowin up space nerds with my pink battleships :)

10/10 would fire all Lazors again"
